#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Hide
#Text=Things in a Book
#Text=You can make a hollow book for hiding large items inside of a book but what about the simple act of hiding slim items such as money , secret notes , or printed information inside a book ?
#Text=Is it safe and reliable ?
#Text=It is , provided you are careful about how you do it !
#Text=It is also important to remember which book you have hidden your money or notes .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Small hideaway compartment
#Text=Choose a good book .
#Text=The following requirements are essential :
#Text=The book must be thick to make it harder to spot anything stuffed into it .
#Text=It should be inconspicuous .
#Text=Choose a book that belongs on the shelf amid other books ; do n't choose one that looks obviously out of place .
#Text=Spacious and of adequate size to conceal your goodies .
#Text=You could hollow out a book but that 's more work and is often noticeable .
#Text=If you 're just looking to hide flat things , a normal book works just fine .
#Text=Find a good placement inside the chosen book .
#Text=Try to put your stash about 3 quarters of the way into the book .
#Text=People will see it in the middle and it 'll fall out if it 's in the end .
#Text=And the beginning is just too obvious .
#Text=Remove any signs of disturbance around the shelf .
#Text=If you have disturbed any dust or fluff bunnies in doing this , you 'll just have to clean the whole shelf or else it will look obvious .
#Text=Remember the book .
#Text=Work out a way for reminding yourself which book or books you have chosen to hide things in .
#Text=If you own a lot of books , it is not unknown to forget where you hid that " money for a rainy day " , only to have a pleasant surprise many years later !

column1: #Text=Large hideaway compartment
#Text=This method is more useful if you have a bit more voluminous stuff to hide , like a diary .
#Text=Find a thick and very large book that you wo n't ever want to read again .
#Text=Hardcover is your best bet and old encyclopedias , reference manuals and your old college textbooks can come in handy here .
#Text=You 'll also need a pen , an exacto knife and glue for this .
#Text=If you ca n't find a large book at home , try the thrift store or a used book store .
#Text=Or , ask for one via a site like Freecycle .
#Text=If you are hiding a diary inside it , measure the ability of the book to cope with this object before cutting it .
#Text=Open the book .
#Text=Flip over the first 20-40 pages or so , depending how much room you want inside the book .
#Text=Draw a rectangular shape on the next page from the ones flipped over .
#Text=Make it the size you want , leaving an inch ( 2.5cm ) allowance as borders around the hole space , or it will look too obvious when completed .
#Text=Carefully cut out the rectangular hole with the Exacto knife .
#Text=Repeat the last two steps if your book is particularly thick .
#Text=With the hole now in the book , use an old painting brush to start coating the inside edges of the hole with glue .
#Text=The pages of the book will then stick together and form strong walls for the hideaway compartment .
#Text=Also apply glue to the backside ( either the back cover or one of the remaining pages of the back ) .
#Text=This will make a box , and your things wo n't fall out quite so easily .
#Text=Weight the book down with a few heavy books .
#Text=These will press the glued pages together .
#Text=Set aside and let it dry .
#Text=Fill with your goodies .
#Text=You now have a secret compartment where you can hide your special stuff .
#Text=Snap the book shut and put it away in the bookshelf for safekeeping .
#Text=Video
#Text=Tips
#Text=Put the book away after .
#Text=A random book sitting around is not hard to see .
#Text=If it 's a diary you 're hiding do n't try a book .
#Text=Try a box .
#Text=Things You 'll Need
#Text=Something to hide
#Text=A thick inconspicuous book
#Text=Clutter ( optional )
#Text=Feather duster
